content: I've decided to enlist into the air force and have been trying to prepare everything year in advance to be ready. Last year i started getting head aches a lot and realized that im alittle near sighted in my left eye. So, the doctor prescribed me only one contact. i try to use them as much as possible to keep away from having any headaches. i was wondering if the military would let me use my contact any since it only makes a little difference. i do know to make sure to take it off with in the 2nd or 3rd week for the gas chamber.
reply: I've decided to enlist into the air force and have been trying to prepare everything year in advance to be ready. title: Wearing contacts

content: As long as whatever military branch you choose is aware of that and that you remember you need to take it out when the need arises! There shouldn't be any problem! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: As long as whatever military branch you choose is aware of that and that you remember you need to take it out when the need arises! There shouldn't be any problem! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: Wearing contacts

content: Depend somewhat on the job you go for, but the military will provide glasses for you, usually shatter proof lenses. I've still got a pair from the Air Force I use to read with. It used to be the rule you couldn't wear contacts, because watching an electronic spark like welding or a glitch in electronics might weld them to the surface of your eyeball via electrolysis or something... Anyway, because I worked in a Radar Van full of electronics, contacts were tabboo, but I hated them becasue they get dust under them. So I preferred glasses anyway - that corrected my vision to 20/10 - great for Radar Scope work, but also great for observation, hunting, and seeing police cars at 2-3 miles on the freeway!! If your vision is good enough you barely need correction in just one eye, you should have no problem. When I enlisted, mine was 20/25 and 20/30 - no problem - - Just kept me from being a pilot was all - - Air Force Forums might be a better place to ask - - http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/cfrm/f/65919558 Wandering and Wondering
reply: Depend somewhat on the job you go for, but the military will provide glasses for you, usually shatter proof lenses. I've still got a pair from the Air Force I use to read with. It used to be the rule you couldn't wear contacts, because watching an electronic spark like welding or a glitch in electronics might weld them to the surface of your eyeball via electrolysis or something... Anyway, because I worked in a Radar Van full of electronics, contacts were tabboo, but I hated them becasue they get dust under them. So I preferred glasses anyway - that corrected my vision to 20/10 - great for Radar Scope work, but also great for observation, hunting, and seeing police cars at 2-3 miles on the freeway!! If your vision is good enough you barely need correction in just one eye, you should have no problem. When I enlisted, mine was 20/25 and 20/30 - no problem - - Just kept me from being a pilot was all - - Air Force Forums might be a better place to ask - - http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/cfrm/f/65919558 Wandering and Wondering
title: Wearing contacts

title: Wearing contacts

content: I don't even know if contacts had been invented when I was in Vietnam (70-71), but if I'd had them, I wouldn't have worn them in the bush. Too much dirt to deal with. I suspect you may find the same problem in the desert environments of Iraq or Afgnanistan. On the other hand, I couldn't wear my regulation issue Army glasses while humping either. The sweat caused them to keep slipping down my nose. I didn't even wear them while walking point, a fact which I'm sure didn't lend confidence to those walking behind me. M-16's: Ours was the first cycle of trainees to use the M-16 at Ft. Polk, LA and that was in November, 1969. One wonders why it took the Army so long to convert training from the M-14 to the one most of the troops would actually use in the war we were all going to. Surprisingly, the ones we were issued for training were worn slap out. SOMEBODY had been using them somewhere!
reply: I don't even know if contacts had been invented when I was in Vietnam (70-71), but if I'd had them, I wouldn't have worn them in the bush. Too much dirt to deal with. One wonders why it took the Army so long to convert training from the M-14 to the one most of the troops would actually use in the war we were all going to. Surprisingly, the ones we were issued for training were worn slap out. SOMEBODY had been using them somewhere!

content: In 1969 I joined the Army and we used M-1 garands in Basic training. Those were the same rifles used in WW-2 and in Korea. Talk about being well used. We were issued M-14's when I got to my standard unit.

title: Wearing contacts

content: No BS... It was during that era when there were a lot of complaints about trainees being made to do too many pushups as punishment, or being yelled at for dropping out during PT and field marches, etc. You ever hear of "time out" cards?? Well, anyway, because of the same kinds of complaints, mostly by parents to Congressmen, etc., the gaschamber experience could be at the discretion of the trainee... In other words, they could "observe" rather than go in, and not have it held against them as a deficiency in training... I haven't heard if it has swung back the other way over the years, but that is the last I heard - - I tried to run down any references and couldn't find much... But it seems to be mandatory again...probably since Desert Storm and the fear of Chemical Warfare against Saddam... It was during the 80s and may have been short-lived . . I got gassed so many times in training (agressors and friendlies both were throwing CS or CN all the time) that I got to were I wouldn't even mask - just move up wind/cross wind to get out of it, wait for it to blow away and get back to business - - This message has been edited. Last edited by: greywolfghost, Sat 25 April 2009 02:13 PM Wandering and Wondering
reply: No BS... It was during that era when there were a lot of complaints about trainees being made to do too many pushups as punishment, or being yelled at for dropping out during PT and field marches, etc. You ever hear of "time out" cards?? Well, anyway, because of the same kinds of complaints, mostly by parents to Congressmen, etc., the gaschamber experience could be at the discretion of the trainee... In other words, they could "observe" rather than go in, and not have it held against them as a deficiency in training... I haven't heard if it has swung back the other way over the years, but that is the last I heard - - I tried to run down any references and couldn't find much... But it seems to be mandatory again...probably since Desert Storm and the fear of Chemical Warfare against Saddam... It was during the 80s and may have been short-lived . . I got gassed so many times in training (agressors and friendlies both were throwing CS or CN all the time) that I got to were I wouldn't even mask - just move up wind/cross wind to get out of it, wait for it to blow away and get back to business - - This message has been edited. Last edited by: greywolfghost, Sat 25 April 2009 02:13 PM Wandering and Wondering
